title: Friday, 8th July, 2016

British American Tobacco PLC (BATS:LSE): Last: 4,839, down 108.5 (-2.19%), High: 4,933, Low: 4,825, Volume: 953.15k
11:12 am
BE

Barclays saying "enough already"

BE

Likewise Diageo.

Diageo PLC (DGE:LSE): Last: 2,120, down 41 (-1.90%), High: 2,169, Low: 2,113, Volume: 1.56m
11:13 am
BE

Sector note, this.

BE

We remain Neutral on Consumer Staples: Two weeks on from the UK Brexit vote and
uncertainty still dominates both politically and economically. Against this backdrop, we
expect investor appetite for risk to remain subdued and for ‘quality’ stocks to continue
to trump any call for a shift into ‘value’ for now. This may well support on-going Staples
sector out-performance over the next three months; however, having already out-
performed substantially since June 23, the associated +4% PE re-rating of European
Staples leaves the sector trading on PE multiple (22.4x) last seen in the early 2000s
Tech Bubble. Despite on-going yield support, without another macro shock it is tough
to argue for a further significant PE re-rating, however with relative earnings support
likely to continue we maintain our Neutral sector stances.

BE

22.4 times! For soup and ice cream!

11:14 am
PM

hehehehe

BE

FX driven earnings upgrades offset recessionary concerns: We adjust our estimates
across our European Staples universe to take account of FX movements and our
economists’ more cautious European GDP estimates. FX has prompted a +1.6% upgrade
to Staples EPS, while a -140bps cut to 2017 euro area GDP estimates and -230bps
reduction to the UK reduce our Staples estimates by -0.3% on average. The relatively
benign impact on the sector is testament Staples’ defensive characteristics and the fact
that less than 35% of Staples’ sales are sourced from Europe.

BE

Heineken (PT €90): With the naira devalued and margin expansion structurally
supported by the group’s growth-skewed footprint in Asia and Mexico, medium-term
margins may beat guidance of 40bps p.a. and prompt upgrades to F17E in our view.
Nestlé (PT CHF82): Given the uncertain macro backdrop, the combination of Nestlé’s
geographic/product diversity, dividend yield, new CHF 1.8bn cost saving plan and
prospect for positive strategic change under the new external CEO is appealing. We
expect the shares to re-rate from a discount to premium to the sector.
Diageo (PT 2150p): Momentum is improving but the recent re-rating has closed the
stock’s historical PE discount. Although we see reasons for earnings upside from greater
efficiency savings and incremental cash returns, with neither likely until 2017 and without
on-going GBP weakness, the shares lack a catalyst for further out-performance.
BAT (PT 5100p): Although we remain positive on the tobacco sector and BAT’s ability to
beat EBIT margin expectations over the medium-term (driven by SAP deployment), after
recent out-performance, our upside case fair value is less than 10% away.
Other stocks to consider: We re-iterate our OW on Britvic which is now trading at
decade relative lows, Imperial Brands as it should close its relative PE discount to Staples
and Rémy Cointreau, which is enjoying transactional FX support.

11:15 am
BE

145 pages. That was the first.

BE

Contact Barclays direct for the other 144.

undefined
11:16 am
PM

See there's some knife catching in commercial real estate

PM

UBS reckon the market is pricing in 60-70% falls

PM

Which does seem a tad extreme

11:16 am
PM

Uncertainty dominates, but compensated for by attractive returns
Post the EU referendum we have called all our UK REITs and a number of property
agents, including CBRE, JLL and Savills. Uncertainty dominates. Clearly investment and
(to lesser extent) leasing transactions are 'on hold'. The stock market has been quickest
to react, we think now pricing in 60-70% of a 1980s/2008-style decline, as implied
yields have blown out c80-90bps to 5.7% (close to record spread over gilts), NAV
discounts widen to 30-40% and discounts to appraised value (GAV) to c25-30% (close
to historic extreme). While uncertainty means volatility is likely to remain, fundamentally
we feel the REITs are better positioned than the market credits and have been
disproportionately punished. In this new environment we see Land Sec as best
positioned. While the market has been caught by surprise, Land Sec has been preparing
for this for two years, with low leverage, firepower if required and little downside risk.

PM

Yields 5.7%

PM

Limited evidence, but impact likely mitigated
At this stage, there is limited evidence to assess the magnitude of the impact. Property
funds have nudged valuations down 5-10% and closed to redemptions. The long-term
demand picture in London is uncertain. While the direction is down, we see a number
of factors that should mitigate the impact: (1) The global search for yield continues to
exert a bid for real estate, with implied yields of 5.5% backed by 7-10 year average
lease length (2) REITs have positioned conservatively and with LTVs close to 20% (a) will
likely not breach covenants and (b) could acquire distressed assets; while (3) vacancy
rates are low (sub 5%), pipelines are likely to be shelved, offsetting the demand impact.
Changes to ratings and price targets: Land Securities top pick
We move to the stress case presented in our 'Deep Dive' and 'Be Prepared' notes.
Broadly, we mark London offices values down 20%, UK retail down 15%, Industrial
and London retail down 5-10%. We cut price targets by an average 21%. NAVs are
cut 23%. The low levels of leverage across the London exposed names mitigate the
downside. We downgrade one rating: Intu to Neutral.
Valuation
The UK trades at a 24% discount to our (written down) year-end NAVs. Our PTs are
based on our economic profit method and equate to a 5-10% discount to NAV t+2.

11:17 am
BE

Hm.

PM

Ah, and UBS also reckon the housebuilders are over sold

PM

Think the market has already priced in a 10% price drop and 25% volume drop

11:18 am
PM

hmm

PM

As we've noted before, there's bound to be huge divergence depending on location

PM

Here's what they're saying anyway

11:18 am
PM

Analyst is Gregor Kuglitsch

PM

Sector looks oversold
We think the c40% share price fall of the sector post EU referendum is overdone, and
suggests an attractive entry point over our forecast horizon. We recognise the range of
potential outcomes remains wide, but believe the market is relatively close to pricing in
10% house price deflation and a 25% volume drop, which we estimate implies a
further 10% share price downside. Our new base case of -5% price and -15% volume
cuts estimates by c40% and PTs by 35%, on average; but we see average upside
potential from here of c40% across the sector on a 12-month view. Until clarity
improves we believe volatility is likely to remain high, but we see upside potential in the
sector. While we believe the whole sector is cheap, our top picks are Bellway, Berkeley
and Persimmon, which offer the most attractive risk/reward in our view.

PM

What is different to 2008? Sector well positioned to absorb a downturn
We believe the sector is in a fundamentally different position to the 2008/9 downturn:
(1) balance sheets are strong with a sector net cash position and only £2bn of land
creditors vs total leverage of £6bn in 2008; (2) no visible signs of distress in the financial
system, hence we see no reason to expect any sharp reduction in mortgage lending; (3)
Help to Buy remains in place which should assist new build transactions; (4) the land
market running up to H116 was benign, meaning land bank margins are at record
levels compared with the compressed levels of 2008; (5) Apartment content (ex.
London) is very low, which should limit distressed selling. Key from here will be changes
to unemployment rates and shifts in consumer confidence, which will likely determine
trading conditions.

11:19 am
PM

New scenarios: upside and downside from here
We expect FCF generation to remain strong as land prices adjust and companies reduce
land buying and switch focus to cash generation. We expect dividends to be
maintained in our base case scenario; with the sector on an average 9% yield, which is
1.5x covered by FCF and 1.4x by EPS in 2017E on our new forecasts. Our upside
scenario, which assumes no material deflation and slight volume growth implies c70%
share-price upside, on average; and our downside scenario (a further 10% volume drop
to -25% and -10% price deflation) suggests a further 10% downside to the sector.

PM

I wont bother with the Q&A thing UBS do with everything now

BE

Housebuilders, I can see an argument for. Britain's dysfunctional relationship with housing, in addition to the sector's post-2008 debt shakeout and cartel characteristics, make them look a reasonable bet.

Founded in 1982, Cypress is the leader in advanced embedded system solutions for the world’s most innovative automotive, industrial, home automation and appliances, consumer electronics and medical products. Cypress’s programmable systems-on-chip, general-purpose microcontrollers, analog ICs, wireless and USB-based connectivity solutions and reliable, high-performance memories help engineers design differentiated products and get them to market first.

11:30 am
BE

BE

Anyway, we note it. We flag it up. The rumour's rife so we wouldn't be doing our jobs if we didn't flag it up.

BE

If anyone needs to say anything, this might prompt them to. If nothing needs to be said, it won't.

Avanti Communications Group PLC (AVN:LSE): Last: 22.75, down 5.25 (-18.75%), High: 25.25, Low: 20.00, Volume: 1.22m

11:39 am
PM

BE

Now, even before going into how it books revenue, I'm struggling to make an investment case for any company that hasn't been free cashflow positive since 2007.

11:40 am
BE

And whose revenue revenue doesn't seem to have any kind of correlation with that free cashflow.

BE

Jefferies sees one, though. Stays on buy, albeit without a reason.

BE

Avanti has updated the market today with it FY16 revenue performance
(broadly in-line) but negative news around the need to raise additional finance
- it is focusing on an ECA facility that is contingent on $50m of fresh equity.
As a result Avanti has appointed advisers to approach potential new investors,
including "strategic investors", suggesting a sale of the company is also being
considered.
FY16 full year revenue: Avanti is set to deliver FY16 revenue of $83m, which is broadly
in-line with consensus and the previously guided to constant FX growth rate. new contract
wins in 4Q16 have been $70m. Cash the year end is $57m.
Economic backdrop: Avanti has said that the economic backdrop is challenging. Currency
depreciation has resulted in the need for the Company to help some smaller broadband
service providers through exchange rate adjustments. Elsewhere, larger distributers are
requesting longer credit terms, impacting Avanti's working capital. As a result, Avanti has
said the previously guided 50% recurring revenue growth target will be reduced in FY17,
impacting EBITDA.
Funding: Avanti has now signalled that funding is becoming stretched. In reference to the
previously signalled "additional financing facilities", Avanti confirms that that it is at the
final stages in a negotiation with an Export Credit Agency. The ECA funding is contingent
on $50m of new equity being raised. As a result, Avanti is discussing an equity issue with
potential investors through its advisers. The release also speaks of approaches to "strategic
investors" suggesting that industry buyers are being courted. To alleviate near term funding
challenges, Avanti has also identified possible cost saving initiatives and capex savings,
aggregating to $58m over a three-year period. Avanti makes it clear that if the equity funding and, subsequent ECA funding, is not secured it has sufficient liquidity through to 2Q17 (4Q16 calendar).

Post Brexit Albert

11:46 am

Great ................

PM

PM

I'’m going to resist the urge to write about Brexit as you all must be so bored by it by now.

11:46 am
PM

Ah, but luckily he is writing about Brexit

PM

I can’t promise I might not write about it later though, perhaps when tempers subside a bit.
But my views closely coincide with UK philosopher/economist John Gray, that the vote
represents a seismic global shift that will leave the political elites gasping for breath as an
increasingly rebellious electorate seek to throw off the establishment yoke (article here).

PM

In a sign that the UK government has understood nothing from the Brexit vote, what
was George Osborne’s first move after abandoning his pre-election threat of an emergency
budget to raise taxes and cut spending to fill any fiscal hole Brexit might leave? Why he
thought it was a great idea to cut corporation tax from an already low 20% to 15% - it was
28% when he came to power in 2010. These are exactly the policies that have alienated UK
blue collar voters and prompted them to vote for Brexit en masse. For despite the
government mantra after the 2008 financial crisis that “we are all in this together”, the UK
has seen tax rises for the 99% and benefit cuts for the poor while at the same time finding
the money to slash corporation tax! And they wonder why they lost the referendum? As for
the performance of Bank of England Governor, Mark Carney I reaffirm my 2013 view.

11:47 am
BE

And this is the light preamble before he drops something even bleaker to bring to the table. I know how Albert notes work.

PM

The John Grey piece he's referring to is here: http://www.newstat...h-liberal-politics

PM

The rest of the note is about how Italy is imploding, which looks a fair enough analysis

undefined

11:48 am
Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 263.20, down 15.9 (-5.70%), High: 273.00, Low: 258.30, Volume: 1.92m
BE

A few downgrades around post yesterday's numbers.

BE

Morgan Stanley being the main one, but it caught my eye that Goldman's also a seller.

11:50 am
BE

We wrote about the downgrade at the time: https://next.ft.co...-9d4d-c11776a5124d

BE

Goldman was of course Sports Direct's counterparty to its wild punts on Debenhams etc, as well as shop broker.

BE

That hasn't stopped analyst Richard Edwards to reach what seems to be exasperation with the company.

11:52 am
BE

UK referendum, poor weather, online channel shift, and now
adverse consumer behaviour?
To put the recent fade in Sports Direct’s revenue growth into context (we estimate LFL:
1H16 flat, 2H16 -2%), while recent weather patterns will not have helped and post-EU
referendum consumer uncertainty looks to have affected the last few weeks trading, we
believe there is increasing evidence that a change in consumer behaviour is also driving
weaker UK clothing market sales patterns.
Exhibit 1 shows that, over the last year, the UK apparel market growth rate (+2.5% pa 2006-
15) has moved into decline as average selling prices (ASPs) have continued to fade (c.-5%
2006-15 CAGR) alongside slowing volume growth trends. In short, a trade-down dynamic
that has driven lower ASPs and strong volume growth for c.8 years, appears to have stalled
around 18 months ago.

BE

BE

Notably, this has not been driven by an especially weak consumer. Despite recent
moderate growth trends in disposable income, the UK clothing market has, unusually,
underperformed the broader non-food retail sector over the last 18 months. While this
could be explained simply by a prolonged period of adverse weather, we argue that 18
months seems too long a time period for clothing underperformance to be explained by
weather alone. Other explanations used by the industry are that consumers have got
‘enough stuff’ (so called ‘stuffication’) and buying ever greater volumes of clothing is
getting harder/undesirable.
Alternatively, there is the Millennial consumer explanation, which centres on the idea that
consumers are more interested in experiences, family and the home, than purchasing
evermore clothing and shoes. The latter seems to fit the data (see below) to the extent that
the strongest performing non-food retail categories over the last 18 months have been
home related (and in particular furniture), while clothing performance has been
deteriorating.

11:53 am
BE

Millennials buying "experiences" rather than trainers.

PM

stuffication. I hope there's something in this

BE

Any time I read (as I seem to a lot) that Millennials are buying "experiences" my mind goes instantly to the kind of experiences the Millennials I know tend to buy.

11:54 am
BE

As in, usually in a small bag from a club toilet.

BE

But anyway.

BE

Here's Morgan Stanley's downgrade, when it opens.

11:55 am
BE

Although today's results were in line with our expectations, the
accompanying analyst meeting has left us distinctly uncomfortable
with both our previous forecasts and our previous investment thesis.
We cut our FY 2016/17 earnings estimate by nearly 50% and reduce
our rating to Equal-weight

BE

Cutting our losses. Sports Direct shares are down more than 30% on an
absolute basis, and more than 10% relative to the sector, since we upgraded
the stock in February. Nevertheless, two key recent developments have left us
questioning both our previous investment thesis and our previous forecasts,
so we see little choice but to downgrade back to Equal-weight.
Sports Direct's lack of hedging means we now assume a 500 bps fall in
gross margin in FY 2016/17e. The first key development is the weakness in
Sterling following the Brexit vote and Sports Direct's disclosure that it had
chosen not to hedge its currency exposure (c.50% of its product is sourced in
US $). With most of its competitors likely to be hedged for the next 6-12
months and its price architecture determined largely by branded product
(which is generally sourced in Sterling), we believe that Sports Direct has little
scope to put up its prices in the near term. We think, therefore, that the fall in
Sterling is likely to cause gross margins at Sports Direct to fall by around
500bps in FY 2016/17e, though we would expect much of this to be recovered
over the longer term .
It now appears to us that the poor trading of recent months has been
caused, at least partly, by lack of access to branded product. Today's
analyst meeting was our first chance to hear management explain what has
caused the deterioration in trading performance that has been evident since
the beginning of the year. We had previously assumed that the principle issue
related to management giving too much space/prominence to own brand
products - a problem that management could fix quite quickly. Management
comments today, however, left us with the impression that the main problem
was the major brands (ie Adidas and Nike) restricting Sports Direct's access to
their product ranges - something over which management has much less
control.

BE

Lead analyst's Anisha Singhal. Very good retail team over there, as we say ad nauseum.
